    Using different rootFUN in geex

    Bradley Saul

    2017-07-10

    Choice of rootFUN

    By default, geex uses the rootSolve::multiroot function for finding roots of a set of estimating equations when compute_roots = TRUE in estimate_equations(). However, a user can choose a different root find find algorithm via the rootFUN argument.

    For example, consider the following eefun which is Huber’s estimator for the center of symmetric distributions [@stefanski2002; example 6]. This example was chosen because it has a single root, so that the stats::uniroot function can be used to find the roots.

    eefun <- function(data, k = 1.5){
  function(theta){
    x <- data$Y1 - theta[1]
    if(abs(x) <= k) x else sign(x) * k
  }
}

    Internally, eefun is used to build \(G_m = \sum_{i = 1}^m \psi(O_i, \theta)\) or in psuedo-code f = sum(inner_eefun(theta)). f is passed to the root finding function along with options in the rootFUN_control arguments. For example, multiroot requires f and start (starting values for the algorithm:

    multiroot_results <- estimate_equations(
  eeFUN = eefun, 
  data  = geexex,
  rootFUN_control = list(start = 3))

    The stats::uniroot function, however, requires the arguments f and interval (or lower and upper)

    uniroot_results <- estimate_equations(
  eeFUN = eefun, 
  data  = geexex,
  rootFUN = stats::uniroot,
  rootFUN_control = list(interval = c(0, 10)))

    Comparing results:

    multiroot_results$estimates - uniroot_results$estimates
    ## [1] 6.244897e-07

    They are basically the same, but this may not be true depending f and the options given to the root finder.

    Building a custom root finder

    All that is necessary for rootFUN is a function where:

    • the first argument is the function whose roots are sought
    • the output is a named list where the root estimates can be identified by the rootFUN_object argument in estimate_equations. For example, both uniroot and multiroot return a list where the root estimates are in the item named “roots”. The default is rootFUN_object = 'roots', so this option works for both uniroot and multiroot.

    Contents
